results.title: Cairo: as told by Youssef Chahine
results.creator_credit: Misr International Films, Miroirs, Mustapha Abdel Aziz and Youssef Chahine
results.brief_description: Personal documentary essay on the city of Cairo by renowned Egyptian filmmaker Youssef Chahine. Director of over forty films, Chahine is renowned for his diverse styles and often controversial subject matter. “Cairo as told by Youssef Chahine” began as a commission by French TV for the news series Envoye Special. Using his unique sense of artistic digression, Chahine begins the film by poking fun at conventional travelogue imagery of Cairo, before going on to explore, from a deeply personal perspective, the contemporary political, religious and social life of the city he loves. The film was banned in Egypt for showing too much dirt.

results.title: Caffeine file
results.brief_description: A humorous look at the problem of caffeine consumption. An anonymous trenchcoated investigator tracts down the caffeine content of many commonly used items. Typical consumers of caffeine are shown to be the coffee junkie, the soft drink addict, the pill popper and children.

results.title: Cafe and Boxes
results.creator_credit: Sydney Dance Company and Geoffrey Nottage
results.brief_description: Two dance films based on productions conceived and performed by the Sydney Dance Company. “A day in the life of a Darling cafe” is the theme of ‘Cafe’ (62mins. 1995), written and choreographed by dancers Paul Mercurio and Kim Walker. The production resembles a mix between a serious dance work and a satirical cabaret piece and is a behind-the-froth study of cafe society. Music by Brett Cabot and Colin Newham. ‘Boxes’ (60mins. 1985) was conceived by Iva Davies, Bob Kretschmer and Graeme Murphy as a dance work which was first performed by the Sydney Dance Company and the band ‘Icehouse’ at the Sydney Opera House on November 7, 1985.

results.title: Cafe
results.brief_description: This first film of writer, actor, director Craig Hoogendoorn, revolves around the cafe conversations of three groups of people - the lovers in the midst of a breakup, the male whining to the female about his ex-girlfriend’s behaviour and the three friends celebrating single life. Shot in black and white the camera plays back and forth between the three groups, catching their conversations in mid-flight. Witty and technically faultless, the film is a promising debut for this young Canberra based filmmaker.

results.title: Cadet worlds: Portugal, 1974
results.creator_credit: Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production and Don Anderson
results.brief_description: Two helmsmen from Tasmania were selected to represent Australia in the 1974 ‘cadet’ Dinghy World Championships. Beginning with the Tasmanian crews mid-winter training at the Sandy Bay Sailing Club in Hobart, the action culminates in the competitions sailed in Portugal.

results.title: Cadet Rousselle
results.brief_description:
In love with the mayor’s daughter, Cadet-Rousselle is separated from his love by money and by low-born parentage. Thus, he heads to Paris to find fame and fortune and make himself worthy of his sweetheart. En route Cadet-Rousselle gets mixed up with a band of gypsies who plan to help the Royalists topple the new French Republic. Adventure piles upon adventure as Rousselle narrowly escapes death at every turn. With him all the way is the new love of his life, fiery gypsy lass Violetta.

Credits: Producer, Rene Bezard ; director, Andre Hunebelle ; writers, Jean Halain, Jean-Paul Lacroix ; photography, Marcel Grignon ; music, Jean Marion.
Cast: Francois Perier, Dany Robin, Bourvil, Christine Carrere, Madeleine Lebeau, Alfred Adam, Jacques Dufilho.

results.title: Cadet Rousselle
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, James Beveridge and George Dunning
results.brief_description: Animated puppets illustrate the old French satirical song about Cadet Rousselle, ostentatious, affected, the clown of the period between the French Revolution and the military order of Napoleon. Cadet Rousselle falls down a ladder, trips on battlements, even his dogs will not obey him. Animation: George Dunning, Colin Low Award: Gardone
